contextual_info.app_usage_reason: Leila uses the app to feel connected to friends from college, particularly after transferring schools due to experiencing racial harassment. She finds comfort in knowing what others are listening to and uses it to feel included.
contextual_info.privacy_expectations_and_vulnerabilities: Leila expects the app to show her only publicly shared content and does not fully understand the visibility settings. She mistakenly assumes others won’t know she’s viewing their activity. She is emotionally vulnerable due to recent isolation and tends to over-share without understanding consequences.
contextual_info.information_to_control: She cares about controlling what music others associate with her identity, especially songs related to her cultural background and emotional states.

privacy_tensions_and_costs.specific_privacy_response: Controlling Disclosure—Leila manages multiple profiles and toggles visibility settings, hoping to see others without being seen.
privacy_tensions_and_costs.costs: Emotional labor, risk of exposure, misunderstanding of app's logic leads to unwanted visibility and unintentional self-disclosure

privacy_invasive user journey.background: In the middle of the semester, Leila moves to a new university and feels increasingly disconnected from her old friend group. Late one evening, she installs the music app on her desktop and begins exploring the 'Friend Activity' feature, hoping to see what her old friends are listening to so she can feel close to them again. She doesn’t realize that enabling visibility on her own listening habits is required to view theirs. Her goal is to silently observe what friends are playing without revealing her own listening history.
privacy_invasive user journey.unexpected_outcomes: After enabling the 'Share my listening activity' toggle and connecting with Facebook, Leila's profile is now broadcasting every track she listens to. She had been playing several emotional tracks related to her recent trauma, including songs with racial justice themes. A classmate she barely knows—who is mutual friends with one of her old friends—messages her, referencing the song she listened to. Leila is startled and embarrassed. The system (data sender) shared her activity; the classmate (data recipient) received it; Leila (data subject) had not realized she made this data visible. She feels exposed and manipulated, triggering a panic episode.

scenes.scene_description: Leila wants to feel close to her old friend group, so she tries to activate the Friend Activity panel. She hopes to watch what others are listening to, expecting she can do so quietly. She thinks: 'Maybe if I turn this on, I can see what Tasha and Sam are into now.'

contextual_info.app_usage_reason: Carlos lives in transitional housing after leaving a volatile domestic situation. He uses the music app as a mental escape and to feel connected to normalcy by browsing what people are listening to.
contextual_info.privacy_expectations_and_vulnerabilities: He doesn’t fully understand how activity visibility works. Coming from a high-surveillance shelter environment, he assumes platforms are private unless told otherwise.
contextual_info.information_to_control: Carlos is sensitive about revealing music that might imply his location, state of mind, or personal affiliations, especially since he’s still avoiding contact with an abusive former partner.

privacy_tensions_and_costs.specific_privacy_response: Apathy—Carlos believes surveillance is everywhere and that nothing he does online is really private, so he doesn’t adjust settings.
privacy_tensions_and_costs.costs: Exposure to abusive surveillance, retraumatization, limited autonomy in controlling disclosure

privacy_invasive user journey.background: Carlos uses a desktop computer provided in a shared community center. On a rainy afternoon, he opens the music app and explores the 'Friend Activity' feature. He’s curious to see if any of the younger shelter residents are using it and wants to blend in. He clicks through settings assuming nothing he does will matter—he's used to being watched. His goal is to observe others and feel included in something normal.
privacy_invasive user journey.unexpected_outcomes: Carlos forgets that he's connected the music app with his old Facebook account, which still includes his abusive ex-partner. After enabling 'Share my listening activity,' his current listening habits—including tracks about healing, domestic violence, and fear—are broadcast to mutuals. His ex sees this activity and deduces Carlos’s emotional state and likely location. This triggers contact attempts and distress. The system shared sensitive emotional metadata (music selection), Carlos is the data subject, and the ex-partner was the unintended data recipient.
